Package com.txtsoft.txttrafficanalyzer

Class Main

java.lang.Object
com.txtsoft.txttrafficanalyzer.Main
public class Main
extends java.lang.Object
TXTrafficAnalyzer application expects text file "traffic.txt" (lower-case) in application directory to extract how many downloads are indicated in "traffic.txt" and what files, according to files's names have been downloaded. - You can also see the links used to your download files. This is useful to keep or get these links alive. Also dead links cause some traffic, so it is an option to support these for more valid downloads. - The time range of the file is extracted, additionally date and time of first and last download are given out. - Very small project, Eclipse without build tool. - Tested with OpenJDK 13. Only .exe and .zip download files are extracted and counted. Regex pattern used to extract download count information: "(?i)GET .*?\\.(?:zip|exe)" To get a suitable file containing this information go via your host's FTP to directory "logs". There you find suitable files, for example: - "access.log.26.gz" for the calendar week 26 - "access.log.34.4.gz" for the calendar week 34 and the 4th day of the week, that is Thursday These files are all zipped, so unzip for example to "access.log.34.4". Do not forget to copy to application directory and rename to "traffic.txt".
Author:
mb

    • loadText

      public static java.lang.String loadText​(java.io.File f)

      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • loadString

      Loads text from disk using UTF-8 coding.
      Parameters:

      Returns:
      String object of text loaded

    • fActiveJarPathWithoutFilename

      public static java.io.File fActiveJarPathWithoutFilename()
      Path for related JAR-file, i.e. Java program currently executed, is determined and stored in a new file object. This path does not include the JAR-file name. Works correctly under Windows and Linux. Path can contain spaces. Procedure also works, when called in Preloader thread.
      Returns:
      new file object with working program's path. For Windows for example: /E:/PRJ EC/sc/bin/; for Linux for example: /home/mb/Downloads/_200802 sc dist Linux
